author: Dow Jones newswires
title: Former HK leader charged with corruption
text:
Former Hong Kong leader Donald Tsang has been charged by the city's anti-graft agency on two counts of misconduct in public office, becoming the most senior official in the former British colony ever to be arrested.
Mr Tsang, 70, stepped down as Hong Kong's chief executive in July 2012, but has kept a low profile amid an investigation by the Independent Commission Against Corruption after allegations surfaced in early 2012 that he accepted luxury trips and other favors from local businessmen.
The ICAC said Mr Tsang failure to disclose to his cabinet that he entered a lease for a three-story penthouse in Shenzhen from a Chinese tycoon with substantial business interests in Hong Kong. The man was a major shareholder of a digital broadcasting company in Hong Kong, and the company at the time had various license applications that were discussed and approved by Mr Tsang's cabinet.
The second charge relates to his nomination of an architect under the city's honors and awards system, but failed to disclose that he had hired the architect to engage in interior-design work for the Shenzhen flat. Both charges carry a maximum jail sentence of seven years. Mr Tsang has been released on bail but will appear in court later Monday afternoon.
In 2012, Mr Tsang apologised for his acts, which also included joy rides on private yachts and luxury aircraft owned by other tycoons, saying he didn't meet expectations of the public of a leader.
"We learn from our mistakes," he said in March 2012. "We learn to become more sensitive [to public expectations]." He also said at the time he would abandon the penthouse flat in Shenzhen.
On Monday, Mr Tsang said in a statement that he had fully assisted with the ICAC investigations over the past three years. "My conscience is clear. I have every confidence that the court will exonerate me after its proceedings."
